#Text=Store Fresh Mushrooms
#Text=Mushrooms can be one of the hardest vegetables to store because of how quickly they can absorb too much moisture and start to go bad .
#Text=Keeping mushrooms in their original packaging for as long as possible , storing loose mushrooms in a paper bag or paper towels , and freezing mushrooms can all help keep them fresher longer .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Using the Original Packaging
#Text=Keep the mushrooms in their original packaging .
#Text=If you ’re not going to use your mushrooms right away , it ’s okay to leave them in their original cardboard and plastic wrap packaging .
#Text=The plastic wrap usually has holes which allow excess moisture to escape without drying the mushrooms out .
#Text=Rewrap the mushrooms with shrink wrap .
#Text=If you do need a few mushrooms right away , make the smallest hole possible in the original plastic covering .
#Text=Once you ’ve taken the mushrooms you need out of the package , rewrap the area you removed them from with plastic wrap .
#Text=Refrigerate them .
#Text=After you ’ve brought the mushrooms home , refrigerate them in their original packaging .
#Text=Putting fresh mushrooms in the refrigerator slows down the growing process and can prevent them from going bad quickly .
#Text=Using this technique should keep your mushrooms fresh for about a week .
#Text=Using a Paper Bag
#Text=Put mushrooms into a paper lunch bag .
#Text=If you do n’t want to store your fresh mushrooms in their original packaging , you can instead store them in a paper bag .
#Text=The size of the bag can vary depending on how many mushrooms you ’re storing , but brown paper lunch bags are generally the best choice .
#Text=You can also wrap them in damp paper towels before you place them in the bag .
#Text=Leave the paper bag open .
#Text=Do n’t fold over the top of the bag of mushrooms .
#Text=Leaving it open keeps the level of moisture balanced .
#Text=The bag will trap some moisture .
#Text=Leaving it open prevents your mushrooms from soaking up too much moisture .
#Text=Store the bag in your refrigerator .
#Text=You should store the paper bag of mushrooms in your refrigerator , preferably in one of the crisper drawers .
#Text=This keeps the scent and taste of other food from getting into your mushrooms .
#Text=Crisper drawers are also designed to keep fresh vegetables fresher for longer .
#Text=Using this method should keep your mushrooms fresh for a week to 10 days .
#Text=Freezing Mushrooms
#Text=Clean the mushrooms first .
#Text=If you do n't plan to use your fresh mushrooms within a week or so , you 'll want to freeze them to preserve them .
#Text=Start by rinsing the mushrooms under water and then letting them dry in open air .
#Text=You can spread them on a paper or tea towel to catch the excess water .
#Text=Brush with towel or mushroom brush .
#Text=Once the mushrooms are relatively dry , brush them with a paper towel or mushroom brush .
#Text=This gets some of the more stubborn dirt off of them .
#Text=Slice and sauté the mushrooms .
#Text=Slice your mushrooms into even pieces before you sauté them .
#Text=Using an egg slicer can give you uniform pieces .
#Text=Sauté them in one to two tablespoons of olive oil with some salt and pepper to taste .
#Text=Let the mushrooms cool .
#Text=Once you ’ve finished cooking the mushrooms , let them cool before you freeze them .
#Text=Spread them out on a cookie sheet in a single layer until they are cool to the touch .
#Text=Freeze in plastic resealable bags .
#Text=Once the mushrooms have cooled , store them in resealable plastic bags and freeze them .
#Text=Cooking before freezing them prevents them from absorbing too much moisture when they defrost .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Storing in a paper bag can make them shrivel , but it wo n’t hurt them and you can still use them to cook .
#Text=Quick Summary
